            Rehabilitation Project for Poland were as follows: outcomes

            was significant; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory and borrower performance was also moderately
            unsatisfactory. Ratings for the Second Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project for Poland were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome
            was significant; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory and borrower performance was also moderately
            unsatisfactory. Ratings for the Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project for Poland were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory; risk to development outcome
            was significant; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory and borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: when planning
            sequential operations that involve sector reforms, it is
            important to ensure that sufficient disbursement leverage is
            retained to ensure the satisfactory implementation of the
            institutional development components, as well as a realistic
            time-frame for the operation; the use of country systems,
            combined with adequate ex-post audits can contribute to fast
            disbursement of quality works;  it is crucial to take into
            account the budget constraints when using Highway
            Development and Maintenance (HDM) analysis; and objectives
            are more likely to be achieved when they have comprehensive
            monitoring indicators. While proper indicators were set for
            most objectives, there were no indicators linked to the
            objective of achieving reliable and stable funding of road
            maintenance or financial viability. This may have
            contributed to the program's difficulty in achieving
            significant progress on this sub-objective.

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project for Poland were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: with
            regard to the road components, the Government was successful
            in utilizing the country's regional apparatus. The Bank
            approved the medium-term investment plan of the implementing
            agency (MoI/MoT) on the basis of its prior public
            expenditure review and use of HDM-4 (HDM-4 is a software
            tool for the analysis, planning, management and appraisal of
            road maintenance, improvements and investment decisions), a
            rigorous tool for ensuring that investment priorities will
            be based on economic reasoning. The road components, the
            great majority of the projects' funds were quick
            disbursing, with more than $100 million having been
            disbursed in about half a year in each case. Mixing
            quick-disbursing operations with capacity building risks
            disappointment. It was logical for the Bank to offer
            relatively large, quick-disbursing support to a part of the
            infrastructure that is perennially a poor cousin:
            maintenance and rehabilitation, because the new economy of
            the enlarged European Union (EU) is very much reliant on
            intra-EU trade and much of that trade is road-based; and
            because mobility is a fairly high priority among consumption
            goals in new middle income countries. However, institutional
            change is never rapid, even in a literate, educated country,
            especially during a period of political instability. It may
            be tempting to hope that the fast-disbursing elements of a
            project will generate leverage to induce institutional
            change, but success is far from assured. Since the first of
            these loans, the Bank has rightly increased emphasis on
            results as the central criterion for evaluating success and
            hence for orienting management attention, 'what gets
            measured gets managed' both in the Bank and in the
            borrower's administration.

repnme.cdata!: Poland - Making roads safer for all

abstracts.cdata!:
Poland's economic growth and
            transition to a market economy have significantly increased
            the number of cars on its roads and tested the
            government's ability to keep up with the demand for
            more, better, and safer roads. The World Bank has responded
            to this development challenge with multiple roads projects,
            including a United States (U.S.) 29 million dollars
            investment in road safety programs in 1997-2006 under the
            roads second project and the road maintenance and
            rehabilitation project. About 600 people from Poland's
            16 regions went through a five-day course developed under a
            World Bank contract. The World Bank provided crucial
            consultancy that helped things happen on the ground outside
            the usual administrative channels, to make a difference and
            save people's lives.

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Road Maintenance and
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Maintenance and Rehabilitation
            Project will support the rehabilitation, and maintenance of
            economic, social, and institutional roads infrastructure,
            and finance as well consultant services in management and
            training programs. Whereas the loan is essentially focused
            on financing physical investments in road maintenance and
            rehabilitation, it will nevertheless also support to
            improvements in institutional capacity, and support the
            process of road safety improvement. The project components
            will support the modernization action plan (MAP),
            articulated around a diagnosis of the current situation of
            GDDKiA, towards its modernization, and development of
            procedures for implementation of roads projects.
            Reorganization at regional levels will be undertaken,
            supported by the establishment of a strategic planning
            system that evaluates the efficiency of new procedures, to
            ensure modernization, and, to review further potential
            improvements. The road maintenance and rehabilitation
            program will provide financial support, to maintain the
            balance between maintenance and rehabilitation,
            strengthening and reconstruction of existing roads, as well
            as new construction of motorways, and expressways. The road
            safety improvement program on the other hand, will
            contribute to the reduction of road traffic accidents,
            enhancing capacities in crash prevention and mitigation, by
            financing partial support in local initiatives for spot
            mitigation and traffic safety. Increased private sector
            involvement in the financing and operating of road
            infrastructure, and technical assistance will be provided,
            to further define an adequate policy framework, through the
            development of Public-Private Partnerships.

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Third Roads Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment stresses
            the well developed environmental legislation of Poland,
            using both sectoral, and horizontal approaches, as well as
            the traditional regulatory impact on different elements of
            the environment, i.e., air, water, noise. Therefore, even
            those developments which are not covered by mandatory
            environmental impact assessment, will not be exempt from
            compliance with environmental regulations. Furthermore, the
            Polish legislation is compliant with the requirements of the
            European Union environmental legislation. Notwithstanding,
            the review carried out for the purpose of this report
            demonstrates a considerable overlap of two systems, despite
            the following differences in the approaches, and measures:
            1) both the Polish system and the Bank classify projects to
            different categories, depending on the extent of their
            environmental impact; 2) in the Bank procedure, the scope,
            and requirements of environmental assessments (EA) depends
            on the project category - full EA for Category A, and
            limited for Category B projects; 3) public participation is
            initiated at a later stage under the Polish procedure.
            Despite improved EA practices in Poland, some problems
            reveal insufficient expertise on lower administration
            levels, insufficient quality, and often, changes in EA
            regulations have caused problems at county, and municipal
            levels, with little time to adapt to such changes. This EA
            contains a comparison (Polish and Bank system) table of
            project types, subject to an environmental assessment,
            highlighting mitigation measures concerning aquaculture
            aspects; dams and reservoirs; forestry projects, as well as
            deforestation issues; hazardous waste management and
            disposal; large scale industrial plants; irrigation,
            drainage, and flood control issues; Land clearance and
            leveling aspects; manufacture, transportation, and use of
            pesticides, or other hazardous materials; mineral
            development, including oil and gas; river basin development;
            power and hydropower development or expansion; water supply
            and wastewater collection, treatment, and disposal; and
            finally, mitigation on construction of major highways of
            rural roads. The Project Operational Manual (volume 2)
            provides specific mitigation measures.

            limited for Category B projects; 3) public participation is
            initiated at a later stage under the Polish procedure.
            Despite improved EA practices in Poland, some problems
            reveal insufficient expertise on lower administration
            levels, insufficient quality, and often, changes in EA
            regulations have caused problems at county, and municipal
            levels, with little time to adapt to such changes. This EA
            contains a comparison (Polish and Bank system) table of
            project types, subject to an environmental assessment,
            highlighting mitigation measures concerning aquaculture
            aspects; dams and reservoirs; forestry projects, as well as
            deforestation issues; hazardous waste management and
            disposal; large scale industrial plants; irrigation,
            drainage, and flood control issues; Land clearance and
            leveling aspects; manufacture, transportation, and use of
            pesticides, or other hazardous materials; mineral
            development, including oil and gas; river basin development;
            power and hydropower development or expansion; water supply
            and wastewater collection, treatment, and disposal; and
            finally, mitigation on construction of major highways of
            rural roads. The Project Operational Manual (volume 2)
            provides specific mitigation measures.
